key_points: Secretary of the Army, Ryan McCarthy, described pre-riot intelligence as inconsistent, with crowd size estimates ranging widely.
McCarthy highlighted difficulties in determining the scale of the threat due to variable intelligence.
6,200 National Guard personnel will be deployed to Washington D.C. for a minimum of 30 days to support post-riot security and the upcoming presidential inauguration.
The deployment is a response to the Capitol riot aimed at supporting traffic control and law enforcement.
The National Guard's presence ensures security for President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration on January 20.
Former presidents and officials have condemned the violent events and the disruption of the electoral process on January 6.
During the Capitol riot, approximately 1,100 National Guard troops were mobilized to assist local law enforcement.
President Donald Trump, who has not conceded defeat, rallied supporters before the riot but has not condemned their actions.
Biden's inauguration plans have been altered due to COVID-19, focusing on virtual participation to prevent the spread.
President-elect Joe Biden condemned the riot, describing it as an assault on democracy and calling for an end to the violence.
